prompt.preamble: We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences. In this activity, we're going to be looking at different strings of text and you'll be deciding if they look like they could be an email address or not. For example, most people would agree that "username@domain.com" looks like an email address, while "n12z5lFEN4" does not. However, the rules for what can be an email address can be very unusual, so what we're really interested in is your intuition on what an email address could look like. Tip: in an email such as username@cs.stanford.edu, "username" is called the local-part of the email, while "cs.stanford.edu" is the domain. Furthermore, "cs" is a subdomain, and "edu" is a top-level domain.
prompt.task_description: your intuition of what is or is not possible for an email address
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of email addresses, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your email preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following strings look like reasonably well-formatted email addresses or not: "yes" if they do, "no" if they don't.

conversation_history.message: Can you describe what kind of special characters, if any, you believe should be allowed in an email address and where they should be placed?
Underscores (_) and periods (.) in the local part of the email.
What are your thoughts on the use of numbers and capital letters in an email address, and do you believe there should be any restrictions on where they can be placed?
Numbers and capital letters can be very useful in conveying a message or branding in the local part of the email.

What are your thoughts on the length of an email address, both in terms of the local part before the '@' symbol and the domain part after it? Do you believe there should be a minimum or maximum length for either part?

Yes, there should be character limits on both parts of the email. At a minimum, you need 1 character on the local part and at least 5 in the domain. Maximums need to be set so that email addresses can be read and recognized by the reciever in order to trust who it is from.

What are your thoughts on the use of special characters like hyphens (-) or plus signs (+) in the local part of the email address, and do you believe there should be any restrictions on where they can be placed?

feedback.feedback_other: It seemed short to cover all the aspects of email addresses.

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn what rules a user believes to be a valid email address format must adhere to (e.g. for developing a regex format checker).

Previous questions:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative open-ended question that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Make sure your question addresses different aspects of the regex than the questions that have already been asked. At the same time however, the question should be bite-sized, and not ask for too much at once. Phrase your question in a way that is understandable to non-expert humans; do not use any jargon without explanation. Generate the open-ended question and nothing else:
